Subject: English
ContentDescription: Investigate how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring culturally specific greetings and expressions of politeness
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •support to interpret and use gesture and body language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Investigate how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring culturally specific greetings and expressions of politeness
EALDElaboration: •demonstrations of use of interactions in a range of contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Investigate how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring first nations australian cultural protocols in welcome to country and acknowledgement of country, and the greeting words used by local first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Investigate how interpersonal language choices vary depending on the context, including the different roles taken on in interactions
Elaboration: Exploring how familiarity with a group or individual influences language choices

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language can be used for appreciating texts, and providing reasons for preferences
Elaboration: Exploring how language is used to appreciate texts using more precise vocabulary; for example, "i liked how the author described the setting because ..."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of visual supports and role play to model expression of preferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language can be used for appreciating texts, and providing reasons for preferences
Elaboration: Exploring verbs used to express degree of preference; for example, "liked", "preferred", "enjoyed"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how language can be used for appreciating texts, and providing reasons for preferences
Elaboration: Identifying first nations australian language words specific to country/place that help the reader to be specific when appreciating the setting in a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the typical features of a text; for example, a typical introduction to a narrative or the use of dot points in instructions
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations and demonstrations of text structures during shared reading of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the typical features of a text; for example, a typical introduction to a narrative or the use of dot points in instructions
EALDElaboration: •links between the purpose and structure of a text demonstrated across a broad range of texts using role play and authentic experiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying that different types of texts might have different forms; for example, an expression of opinion might be in the form of a poster, email or brochure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum are organised differently and use language features depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the organisation and language features in texts such as narratives, recounts, information reports, simple procedures, expression of opinion and responses to texts (including poetry), and discuss their purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Identifying language used to build information across a text; for example, through connecting similar and dissimilar things
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using colour-coding and tracking, when explaining the use of pronouns

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Identifying language used to build information across a text; for example, through connecting similar and dissimilar things
EALDElaboration: •scaffolded speaking activities where students practice pronoun referencing in pairs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Mapping examples of word associations in texts; for example, words that refer to the main character in a story: "isy", "she", "i", "sister", "student"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Tracking how a person or thing is identified through a section of a text; for example, "eggs", "they", "them"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Identifying words left out that can be inferred from the surrounding text; for example, "xanthe went to school. she had a lovely day." (at school is inferred)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how texts are made cohesive by using personal and possessive pronouns, and by omitting words that can be inferred
Elaboration: Using personal and possessive pronouns to link entities previously mentioned in the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Navigate print and screen texts using chapters, tables of contents, indexes, side-bar menus, drop-down menus or links
Elaboration: Recognising how numbered chapters, organisation of tables of content and alphabetical order of indexes operate to support access to information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Navigate print and screen texts using chapters, tables of contents, indexes, side-bar menus, drop-down menus or links
Elaboration: Exploring how the navigation tools of different websites can be used to locate information

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that connections can be made between ideas by using a compound sentence with 2 or more independent clauses, usually linked by a coordinating conjunction
Elaboration: Using coordinating conjunctions; for example, "and", "but", "so" to construct compound sentences; for example, "the wolf huffed / and he puffed / and he blew the house down!"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of sentences using different conjunctions, that students can vary to express their own ideas

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that connections can be made between ideas by using a compound sentence with 2 or more independent clauses, usually linked by a coordinating conjunction
Elaboration: Using coordinating conjunctions; for example, "and", "but", "so" to construct compound sentences; for example, "the wolf huffed / and he puffed / and he blew the house down!"
EALDElaboration: •lists of coordinating conjunctions, matched to their purpose with examples, e.g “Marta likes apples but Adhi likes grapes.”

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that connections can be made between ideas by using a compound sentence with 2 or more independent clauses, usually linked by a coordinating conjunction
Elaboration: Using coordinating conjunctions; for example, "and", "but", "so" to construct compound sentences; for example, "the wolf huffed / and he puffed / and he blew the house down!"
EALDElaboration: •deconstructing and reconstructing sentences using cut up sentences.

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Identifying nouns that refer to people, places, concrete objects and ideas in sentences in texts, and identifying the articles and adjectives that extend those nouns
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •manipulating words in sentences from texts they are using in class, to support understanding of syntax

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Identifying nouns that refer to people, places, concrete objects and ideas in sentences in texts, and identifying the articles and adjectives that extend those nouns
EALDElaboration: •recognising that conventions for the use of articles don’t always apply, for example, the use of the article the to refer to both the specific ‘the cat next door’ and the general ‘the whale is the largest mammal’ and its arbitrary use (for example the Earth, but not the Mars)

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Identifying nouns that refer to people, places, concrete objects and ideas in sentences in texts, and identifying the articles and adjectives that extend those nouns
EALDElaboration: •demonstrations  of how comparative adjectives are formed , using the suffixes ‘er and ‘est’ and used in English for example using ‘more’ for adjectives with three or more syllables (This rule is more important ), and the irregular comparative adjectives such as ‘better,’ not ‘gooder.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Building extended noun groups using articles and adjectives; for example, "the longest side"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Building extended verb groups using verbs; for example, "was touched"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that in sentences nouns may be extended into noun groups using articles and adjectives, and verbs may be expressed as verb groups
Elaboration: Investigating how noun groups can be built up by asking questions about the noun such as "how many?", "what's it like?", "what type?"; for example, "two pairs of old walking shoes"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that images add to or multiply the meanings of a text
Elaboration: Identifying images and graphics in a text that add ideas or information not included in the written text; for example, a map or table in a factual text or an illustration in a story which gives clues about the setting
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of images and graphics that represent a range of cultural contexts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that images add to or multiply the meanings of a text
Elaboration: Identifying images and graphics in a text that add ideas or information not included in the written text; for example, a map or table in a factual text or an illustration in a story which gives clues about the setting
EALDElaboration: •explanation of the cultural assumptions in illustrations

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that images add to or multiply the meanings of a text
Elaboration: Identifying visual representations of characters' actions, reactions, speech and thought processes in narratives, and considering how these images add to or multiply the meaning of accompanying words

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Experiment with and begin to make conscious choices of vocabulary to suit the topic
Elaboration: Selecting vocabulary appropriate to the topic to replace everyday language
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •multiple opportunities to use new vocabulary in guided and independent contexts using visual support

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Experiment with and begin to make conscious choices of vocabulary to suit the topic
Elaboration: Discussing new vocabulary encountered in learning area texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Experiment with and begin to make conscious choices of vocabulary to suit the topic
Elaboration: Exploring language used to describe characters in narratives, including nouns; for example, "magician", "wizard", "sorcerer" and adjectives such as "gentle", "timid" or "frightened"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Experiment with and begin to make conscious choices of vocabulary to suit the topic
Elaboration: Identifying words from first nations australians' languages relevant to a topic

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that capital letters are used in titles, and commas are used to separate items in lists
Elaboration: Identifying how capital letters are used in the titles of texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise that capital letters are used in titles, and commas are used to separate items in lists
Elaboration: Identifying commas used in lists in a variety of types of texts; for example, "this class has students who speak vietnamese, thai and arabic at home."

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literature created by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing the depiction of characters in particular settings in well-known fairytales from wide-ranging world authors; for example, children in forests and royalty in castles and towers
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of familiar stories that reflect their cultural heritage, and opportunities to lead discussions about these texts if the student feels safe and it is culturally appropriate for them to share the information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literature created by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Recognising recurring characters in particular settings in texts by first nations australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how characters and settings are connected in literature created by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the way wide-ranging australian authors and illustrators depict the australian outback and the associated characters

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Identify features of literary texts such as characters and settings, and give reasons for personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing preferences for stories set in familiar or unfamiliar worlds or about characters whose lives are like or unlike their own

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Identify features of literary texts such as characters and settings, and give reasons for personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing their feelings about the positive and negative behaviours of non-human characters such as animals

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the characters and settings of a range of texts, and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Comparing how similar characters or settings are described in texts from different contexts; for example, how the seasons are described
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using texts to demonstrate how appropriate vocabulary choices are made to support meaning

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the characters and settings of a range of texts, and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Identifying and comparing verb groups used to convey actions, emotions and dialogue in a range of literary texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the characters and settings of a range of texts, and identify how language is used to present these features in different ways
Elaboration: Identifying the language used to describe the landscape in first nations australians' stories

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify, reproduce and experiment with rhythmic, sound and word patterns in poems, chants, rhymes or songs
Elaboration: Exploring poems, chants, rhymes or songs from different home languages of class members
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to explain poems or rhymes form their first language or explain how a rhyme pattern has been lost, once a poem or chant is translated into English

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts by adapting structures and language features of familiar literary texts, through drawing, writing, performance and digital tools
Elaboration: Inventing some speech, dialogue or behaviour for a favourite character, which may include the use of video and audio tools, for an alternative event or outcome in the original text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using text frames to scaffold at the sentence and paragraph level

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts by adapting structures and language features of familiar literary texts, through drawing, writing, performance and digital tools
Elaboration: Reviewing and developing sentences; for example, adding prepositional phrases such as "with a long tail" to improve descriptions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how similar topics and information are presented in different types of texts
Elaboration: Reading a poem, narrative and informative text about lifecycles and discussing what is learnt
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •comparing and contrasting language choices between texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how similar topics and information are presented in different types of texts
Elaboration: Exploring recipes presented on food packets, in recipe books, in short video clips and in a digital form, noting their shared purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics: actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements and giving instructions
Elaboration: Exploring ways to comment on what others say, including using sentence starters such as "i like the way you ...", "i agree that ...", "i have a different thought ...", "i'd like to say something different ..."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of how particular types of questions are formed: for example;  What happened? Why did this happen? and appropriate responses, for example this happened because...

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics: actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements and giving instructions
Elaboration: Exploring ways to comment on what others say, including using sentence starters such as "i like the way you ...", "i agree that ...", "i have a different thought ...", "i'd like to say something different ..."
EALDElaboration: •models of how statements can be turned into questions; for example ‘I think I know what will happen next in the story’  becomes ‘What do you think will happen next in the story’?

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics: actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements and giving instructions
Elaboration: Demonstrating appropriate listening behaviours, responding to and paraphrasing a partner's contribution to a discussion; for example, in think-pair-share activities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics: actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements and giving instructions
Elaboration: Asking relevant questions and making connections with personal experiences and the contributions of others

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills when engaging with topics: actively listening to others, receiving instructions and extending own ideas, speaking appropriately, expressing and responding to opinions, making statements and giving instructions
Elaboration: Understanding how to disagree or respectfully offer an alternative

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of imaginative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Identifying the purpose of texts written by first nations australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose and audience of imaginative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Identifying the audience of advertisements and signs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read texts with phrasing and fluency, using phonic and word knowledge, and monitoring meaning by re-reading and self-correcting
Elaboration: Using phonic (sound-letter) and morphemic knowledge, and knowledge of high-frequency words when decoding text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations of cultural references in texts that may be unfamiliar to them; for example explaining the concept of ‘drought’ before reading Jackie French’s book ‘Drought’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read texts with phrasing and fluency, using phonic and word knowledge, and monitoring meaning by re-reading and self-correcting
Elaboration: Using phonic (sound-letter) and morphemic knowledge, and knowledge of high-frequency words when decoding text
EALDElaboration: •choral reading of selections of texts with repeated phrases or refrains, to limit the decoding demands of the text and encourage fluency

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read texts with phrasing and fluency, using phonic and word knowledge, and monitoring meaning by re-reading and self-correcting
Elaboration: Monitoring own reading, self-correcting or reading back, re-reading when meaning does not make sense

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Listening for specific information and providing key facts or points from an informative or persuasive text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations of cultural references that are important to understanding the text, during the initial orientation to the text; for example the concept of ‘convict’ or ‘outback’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Listening for specific information and providing key facts or points from an informative or persuasive text
EALDElaboration: •demonstrations of how to use grammatical constructs and vocabulary to draw inferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Listening and responding to detailed instructions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Integrating information from print, images and prior knowledge to make supportable inferences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Identifying the main idea of a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Predicting vocabulary that is likely to be in a text based on the topic and the purpose of the text; for example, predicting that "station" and "arrive" would be in a text recounting a train journey

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Using prior knowledge to make and confirm predictions when reading a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising, monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning
Elaboration: Using graphic organisers to represent the connections between characters, order of events or sequence of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Creating written texts so that readers follow the sequence of ideas or events
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •teacher-led joint construction with students sharing ideas and the pen to create new types of texts or sentence structures that are likely to be used in the type of text, being constructed

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Using vocabulary, including topic-specific vocabulary, appropriate to the purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Using digital tools to create texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Using simple and compound sentences correctly and flexibly to express and combine ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Editing by adding, deleting or changing vocabulary to improve a text; for example, replacing an everyday noun with a topic-specific one

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit short imaginative, informative and persuasive written and/or multimodal texts for familiar audiences, using text structure appropriate to purpose, simple and compound sentences, noun groups and verb groups, topic-specific vocabulary, simple punctuation and common 2-syllable words
Elaboration: Reviewing sentences for grammatical accuracy; for example, use of pronouns

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations for familiar audiences and purposes, using text structure appropriate to purpose and topic-specific vocabulary, and varying tone, volume and pace
Elaboration: Preparing and delivering oral presentations using more formal language and specific vocabulary about content area topics
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to deliver presentations to smaller group audiences, until they gain greater confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations for familiar audiences and purposes, using text structure appropriate to purpose and topic-specific vocabulary, and varying tone, volume and pace
Elaboration: Preparing and delivering oral presentations using more formal language and specific vocabulary about content area topics
EALDElaboration: •using speaking frames

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations for familiar audiences and purposes, using text structure appropriate to purpose and topic-specific vocabulary, and varying tone, volume and pace
Elaboration: Sequencing ideas, points or events appropriately

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations for familiar audiences and purposes, using text structure appropriate to purpose and topic-specific vocabulary, and varying tone, volume and pace
Elaboration: Adjusting volume and tone when speaking in more formal situations

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words legibly and with growing fluency, using unjoined upper-case and lower-case letters
Elaboration: Consolidating a functional pencil grip/grasp

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Manipulate more complex sounds in spoken words and use knowledge of blending, segmenting, phoneme deletion and phoneme substitution to read and write words
Elaboration: Blending and segmenting sounds in words; for example, "b-r-o-th-er" or "c-l-ou-d-y"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Manipulate more complex sounds in spoken words and use knowledge of blending, segmenting, phoneme deletion and phoneme substitution to read and write words
Elaboration: Deleting and substituting sounds (phonemes) in spoken words to form new words; for example, delete the initial "scr" in "scratch" and substitute new initial sounds (phonemes) to form words such as "catch", "batch" and "hatch"; substituting a medial sound (phoneme) to form a new word; for example, "stack" becomes "stick"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter/s) matches, including vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant clusters and silent letters, when reading and writing words of one or more syllables, including compound words
Elaboration: Reading words with digraphs where one letter is not pronounced; for example, "knife" and "thumb" when reading and using them in writing
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •highlighting letters (graphemes) which produce the same sound (phoneme); for example’ boat’, ‘’know’, as they occur in texts students are reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter/s) matches, including vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant clusters and silent letters, when reading and writing words of one or more syllables, including compound words
Elaboration: Providing the sounds for less common letter-sound matches; for example, "ight" and using them in writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter/s) matches, including vowel digraphs, less common long vowel patterns, consonant clusters and silent letters, when reading and writing words of one or more syllables, including compound words
Elaboration: Reading words with vowel digraphs ("ee", "oo", "ai", "ay", "ea")

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to read and write words whose spelling is not completely predictable from their sounds, including high-frequency words
Elaboration: Using known words and knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to write unknown words; for example, "one", "once", "only" and "lone"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrations of how syntax and word function can support understanding and spelling unfamiliar words, for example tense endings on verbs

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use knowledge of spelling patterns and morphemes to read and write words whose spelling is not completely predictable from their sounds, including high-frequency words
Elaboration: Using context to read the correct word when an unknown word has more than one plausible pronunciation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build morphemic word families using knowledge of prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Using morphemic knowledge of words to spell unknown words; for example, "one", "once", "cover", "covering", "uncover"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •manipulating words, prefixes and suffixes and being given examples of how to use the different forms of the words, for example ‘health’ ‘healthy’; ‘unhealthy’, with attention drawn to their changing functions in sentences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Build morphemic word families using knowledge of prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Writing unknown words using morphemic knowledge; for example, using the known word "friend" to write "friendly" and "friendship"
